posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Our robot is having an issue where the neo550 driving the intake will randomly switch direction. I was wondering if any other teams have experienced this issue.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Just to double-check… are you SURE it’s actually random? No sensor trips, oddball code, weird coincidences like it only does it when you intake your third note after getting hit while ejecting amp, that general sort of thing?

Motors randomly reversing is uncommon… motors seemingly randomly reversing much less so.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
Have you burned flash after setting the motor inversion?

I’ve seen this symptom before with Rev products that reset to initial settings on brownout.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked: This can happen if you are setting the motor controller to be inverted, but not burning the setting to flash memory. A momentary power loss can cause it to revert to the un-inverted state.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I have gone through the code a few times and have found nothing that could cause this issue. However it’s possible there is something I have missed.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: If it’s your code, have someone else take a look. While you’re explaining it to them, any code issues will pop out… funny how that happens.

posts.name: Pizzatc
posts.cooked: While I am not a programmer I would recommend posting your code here. I’m sure someone with an eagle eye may be able to spot it

posts.name: Erik Boyle
posts.cooked:
We fought with this last year. The behavior that we saw was that it would work fine for a while (“a while” was a variable period) before occasionally starting to invert on some startups, with the behavior increasing in frequency until the motor direction seemed to be a random coin flip on every power cycle. When it started inverted, we often could get it to change back to the correct direction by restarting the robot code from the driver station (this seemed to have a >50% chance of toggling the direction of the motor no matter which way it was previously running). We never saw the direction change after a brownout or any other time within a single power up.

We were setting the SPARK Max to inverted, which many have suggested is a factor in the problem, but we were able to watch on the REV Hardware Client and see that the motor controller was still reporting the inverted state as true even when it was not. I haven’t seen anyone confirm whether this matches the expected behavior of this failure mode. We did end up changing the code to burn flash, but the session ended too soon after that for me to say whether it was a permanent fix.

Given the number of other problems that the NEO 550s have, I think the safest option is just to write them off.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads

posts.custom_user_title: Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads

posts.name: Jsteel
posts.cooked: NEO 550s have been good, reliable motors for us.  Not time to write them off.  They are great as a lightweight powerful motor where that is needed.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Did you solve this problem?  Posting when you solve a problem can help someone else solve the same problem down the road.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: We have not found a root cause of it but I inverted it in code and it works again. We’re unsure why it needed to be inverted because the exact same code worked before without it being inverted.

I think this was an issue if you burned flash and didn’t wait a second or if you set the inversion then didn’t wait a second to burn the flash. Either way the ‘patch’ for this is to wrap the set inversion function to set then wait and set the inversion again and again until it’s right. Annoying but not the end of the world.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
